awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Infrapopulation trait distributions link nutrient availability to host-parasite dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The replication rate and harm caused by a parasite can be affected by the nutritional content of its host’s diet. However, the magnitude and direction of these effects vary unpredictably among different hosts and parasites. The goal of this research is to improve our ability to predict how specific parasites will respond to shifts in the nutrient content of their host’s diets. Generating these predictions is important because human activities add nutrients like nitrogen and phosphorus to many ecosystems, directly altering the nutrient content of the diet of animals. Such dietary shifts could favor specific parasites over others. This research will test the hypothesis that the effect of host diet on parasite replication rate is dictated by the flexibility of a parasite’s own nutritional requirements. This project will also improve science education outcomes for students at a local high school. Two high school students will become integral members of the primary research lab for a summer, conducting a small study at the end of their assistantship, and presenting their work to fellow high school students the following year.

The researchers will experimentally manipulate the nutrient content of the diet of an invertebrate host and determine if the relative abundance of carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus in host diets, hosts, and parasites can help predict outcomes for the parasite and host. To rigorously quantify the nutrient content of microbial parasites, the researchers have adapted an energy dispersive spectroscopy workflow previously used to quantify the nutrient content of free-living microbes. Measurements of multiple single celled parasites within a host will be used to create trait distributions of the nutrient content of parasitic populations within a host. These trait distributions capture within-host variation in parasite nutrient content which will be used to estimate the flexibility of each parasite’s nutritional requirements, and, ultimately, to predict the response of each parasite to shifts in the host’s diet.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Predicting the response of parasites to nutrient enrichment is a pressing issue. Some parasites are more abundant in nutrient rich ecosystems, and human activities continue to increase nutrients in virtually all ecosystems. However, parasites vary in their ability to take advantage of nutrient rich environments, so the effects of nutrient enrichment on host-parasite systems are often unpredictable. One aspect of the relationship between nutrient availability and parasites that is particularly poorly understood is the relationship between host diet quality (which is often dictated by ecosystem nutrient availability) and the host-parasite interaction. Important aspects of the host-parasite interaction that could respond to shifts in host diet quality include how abundant the parasite becomes in the host and how much the parasite negatively affects the host.

 

Recent work suggests that we can gain insight into the relationship between host diet quality and host-parasite interactions by measuring the nutrient content of parasites, but, due to logistical issues associated with these measurements, data on parasite nutrient content is rare. Our project advanced the state of this science by, first, outlining a new, rigorous workflow that quantifies the nutrient content of individual microbial parasites, and second, showing that this data can indeed improve our understanding of the effects of host diet on host-parasite interactions.

 

To date, parasite nutrient content has primarily been measured as a single, bulk sample from one or multiple hosts. Our project demonstrated how technology previously used to determine the nutrient content of individual free-living microbes can be repurposed to determine the nutrient content of individual parasitic microbes within their hosts. This method provides rigorous estimates of microbial parasite nutrient content at a novel fine scale.

 

To demonstrate how valuable this fine scale data can be, we experimentally manipulated the diet quality of well-studied (Daphnia magna) hosts infected with two different parasites. Then, we quantified the effects of host diet on the nutrient content and abundance of individual parasites in their host and the negative effects experienced by the host. We also characterized variation in the nutrient content of multiple individual microbes within a host.

 

This experiment showed that host diet influenced the nutrient content and abundance of these parasites in their hosts. Importantly, variation in the nutrient content of parasites within a host explained variation in the abundance of the parasite within a host better than our diet treatments or the average nutrient content of all individuals within a host. This indicates that characterizing this variation provides valuable new insights into the mechanisms by which host diet influences parasites. We also found evidence that parasites can acclimate to their hosts’ diet. A bacterial parasite achieved higher abundances in hosts fed diets that matched the quality of its previous host. This potential for acclimation may help explain inconsistent effects of host diet quality on parasites in previous studies. Follow up experiments at the scale of the host population indicate that the within-host effects of diet quality that we observed in our initial experiment can help explain the abundance of parasites in entire host populations.

 

Broader impacts of this work included the training of 2 graduate students and 6 undergraduate students. Two students from underrepresented groups in STEM were recruited from Carbondale Community high school and trained as paid summer interns in the lab.
